>> - wrong type of String (numeric instead of text, wrong date format...)

> Boo! The problem is that the code is not OO. Where are the number and
> date objects that create themselves from string representations?

How do you handle "5/10/2002" entered on a webpage?  Is it May (US) or November
(Europe)?  What is the most important from the user point of view: the locale
of the server or his locale?
Same thing with numbers: "1,000.10" (US) equals  "1'000,10" or "1.000,10"
(Europe).

Or course your program should handle this gracefully but with a user freely
entering information, you'll have surprises. 

> Not with reflection... as long as you always handle the "null" 
> argument the same way.

we all wait for your automatic reflection tester TestCase :-)  "As long as you
always handle the 'null' argument the same way" is a REALLY strong hypothesis. 
StringBuffer.append accepts null arguments, String.compareTo doesn't.

Anyway, I prefer to focus on positive testing (without forgetting negative
testing, but not spending all my time with this issue).  When the application
does what it has to do, it's already a good result :-)

-Vladimir
